meta.v: Theatro Comico: A Morgadinha de Val-d'Amores; Entre a Flauta e a Viola
Branco, Camilo Castello. Theatro Comico: A Morgadinha de Val d'Amores; Entre a Flauta e a Viola. Porto: Viúva Moré Editora, 1871, 190 p.

text.title: A Morgadinha de Val-d'Amores
text.author: Camilo Castelo Branco

w.comment: 'Abantesma' is a phantom, a spirit out of a body.
'Hirtego' used in the idiom 'teso e hirtego' means 'hirto' ~ rigid .

'Porbolejo' probably means 'percevejo' ~ bedbug, because Saint John the Baptist used to nurture with insects (two pieces of evidence for this claim: the use of 'grilo' ~ cricket in the next stanza, and the existence of an insect in Portugal named 'burrinha de são joão').
The fiddler (rabequista) uses the clitic 'le' in the original, a trace of its spanish origin/influence. (See also 'de pá a pá').

comment.author: A. de Andrade
comment.title: 'de pá a pá' ~ 'de pe a pa'

w.comment: The expression 'de pá a pá' comes from the similar Spanish one 'de pe a pa' meaning "from the beginnning till the end".

w.f: mil oitocentos e setenta e um

w.comment: 'Encosipado' is derivationally related to 'cosido' and means "tightly sewn".
'Vanho' reflects the pronunciation of 'venho' by in current European Portuguese.
'Estifeito' is a variant of 'satisfeito', but with a constant instead of punctual character.
'Crebins' is a reduced form of 'querubins' ("cherubs").
'Nado' is a participle form parallel to 'nascido'.
The expression 'às escâncaras' means "publicly", "open to everybody", and is related to the verb 'escancarar'.
'Moroto' probably means 'maroto' ("rascal").
Asafoetida, the dried latex exuded from the living underground rhizome of some ferula plants.
Asafoetida, the dried latex exuded from the living underground rhizome of some ferula plants.
'Alcaiote' here means a person that spreads gossip (in the general sense, it refers to someone that mediates people).
'Alarve' here means a stupid person.
A person with bad qualities.
Sardanapalo ("Sardanapalus") can be used as a common name meaning "a person with an ostentatious life". It is the greek name of Assurbanipal, the last king of Assyria, in the 7th century BC.
Bernarda refers to the riot being prepared by Macario.
'Canoa' here means a long bathtub.
From Persian 'huri' (woman from paradise) = an extremely beautiful woman.
'Donaire' here means elegance, grace.
A popular dance style of French origin.
'Transe' means a combat, a moment of agony or fear.
'Dar morras' is parallel to 'dar vivas'. They are used when a mob screams repeatedly the respective words of order.
A satrapy located in the south of the Caspian Sea.
'Boucles' is a reduction of the french expression 'boucles d'oreille' meaning "earrings".
Ophicleide is a family of conical-bore keyed bugles. It is the ancestor of the saxophone.
'Mariola' is a scoundrel.
'Caranguejola' here means a society or enterprise lacking trust (from caranguejo, "crab")
A member of a western Germanic tribe (sicambrians, from Latin Sicambri).
'Ademane' is an affected wave.

text.comment: Speech excerpts attributabe to the Minho dialect have been preserved, such as: - ''on" instead of "ão" - "b" instead of "v" Other phonological and lexical specificities will be mentioned during the text. Thanks are due to Mr. Jofre de Lima Monteiro Alves for consultancy.
